results.title: Paint your wagon
results.creator_credit: Joshua Logan, Alan Jay Lerner and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Lee Marvin and Clint Eastwood star in this famous film version of the the stage musical. Ben Rumson (Lee Marvin) is a hard-fighting, hard-drinking, happy-go-lucky man. His ‘Pardner’ (Clint Eastwood) on the other hand is sober, quiet and gentle. The story follows their adventures in a lawless gold mining town called No Name City (population: drunk). They stick together through thick and thin and share everything including a wife (Jean Seberg). Music and lyrics by Alan J. Lerner and Frederick Loewe
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joshua Logan, Alan Jay Lerner and Paramount Pictures

results.title: Miss Sadie Thompson
results.creator_credit: Curtis Bernhardt, Jerry Wald and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Adaptation of W. Somerset Maugham’s “Rain”, a steamy story of sex, sin and salvation in the tropics. Set in the 1940s, it is the story of a bawdy nightclub entertainer, Sadie (Rita Hayworth) and Alfred Davidson (Jose Ferrer), a puritanical preacher waging an anti-sin campaign in the Pacific Islands. When Sadie falls in love with a straight-arrow marine (Aldo Ray), she seeks Davidson’s help in reforming her life. Tragically, the repressed cleric reacts with disbelief and, ultimately violence.

results.title: The Party
results.creator_credit: Blake Edwards, Mirisch Corporation and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Blake Edwards and Peter Sellers combine in another comic masterpiece. This time Sellers is not the bumbling Closeau, but the much maligned and accident-prone Indian actor Hrundi V. Bakshi. Hollywood mogul, Fred Clutterbuck is giving the Hollywood party of the century, complete with beautiful women, powerful men and “wanna-be stars.” Blackballed by his producer for wrecking a day’s shooting, Bakshi finds himself unexpectedly invited to the party. Once this walking disaster area enters the festivities, destruction and mayhem follows. A satire on the artifice and snobbery of Tinseltown and a must for lovers of Sellers’ unique comic style. Co-starring Claudine Longet, Marge Champion and Steve Franken with a musical score by Henry Mancini.

results.title: Bloodlust
results.creator_credit: Jon Hewitt, Richard Wolstencroft and Windhover Productions
results.brief_description: The most controversial and acclaimed cult hit since “Mad Max.” Banned in seven countries including Britain, “Bloodlust” is the tale of three modern day vampires on a bullet-riddled rollercoaster to hell. Winner Finalist Award “Best Film” Worldfest Housten, Texas. Starring John Stuart Wallace, Kelly Chapman, Robert James O’Neill and Phil Motherwell. Music by Revolting Cocks, Pailhead, Lead into Gold and 100 Homo DJ’s.

results.title: Cry-baby = Cry baby
results.creator_credit: John Waters, Rachel Talalay, Imagine Entertainment (US) and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Johnny Depp is Wade “Cry-baby” Walker, a cool, tough but sensitive teenage delinquent. His ability to shed a single tear drives the girls wild. Cry-baby and his friends live on the outer edges of “normal society”. Their “badness” attracts the beautiful rich but square Allison and she is drawn into their rockabilly, fast car world. The soundtrack is excellent, and the rock ‘n roll era of the 1950’s is vividly recreated. Johnny Depp is appealing as Cry-baby and is well supported by co-stars Amy Locane, Susan Tyrell, Iggy Pop, Ricky Lake, Traci Lords and Polly Bergen. John Waters style is firmly stamped on this film as he recreates a nostalgia for an era.

results.title: A Farewell to arms
results.creator_credit: Charles Vidor, David O. Selznick, Selznick Pictures Corporation and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A remake of the 1932 classic tale by famed author Ernest Hemmingway. Rock Hudson stars as an American ambulance driver during World War I. Wounded in action, he is restored to health by an army nurse played by Jennifer Jones. However, their love affair is doomed as the war hangs like a spectre over their lives. Shot on location in the Dolomite region of Italy, the film is sentimentally tragic and never quite reaches the heights of the earlier version. Vittorio De Sica is excellent as the cynical Major Rinaldi, while Hudson and Jones make an attractive couple, but their performances are hampered by a cliched script.

results.title: Germinal
results.brief_description: Emile Zola based “Germinal” on a trip made in 1884 through rural France, observing the conditions of coal miners. This pivotal novel raised awareness of the miners’ plight as they struggled to survive inhumane and dangerous conditions for the profit of the mine owners. Maheu, (Gerard Depardieu) is a miner. He and his wife (Miou Miou) and family eke out a miserable existence in the mines. Their lives are changed when Etienne Lantier (Renaud) enters the district and orginises a miner’s union. Nevertheless, the quest for profit at all costs causes a further disintegration of conditions and results in a terrible mining accident. Despite the almost unrelieved harshness and pessimism of the subject matter, the film is an excellent historical document of an era; vividly contrasting the squalidness of the miners’ lives to the opulent lifestyle enjoyed by the mine owners. French dialogue with English subtitles.

results.title: The Garden of Allah
results.creator_credit: Richard Boleslawski, David O. Selznick and Selznick International
results.brief_description: Domini Enfilden (Marlene Dietrich) devoted her life to caring for her aged father. Upon his death, she decides to make a new life for herself and travels to Algeria. En route she meets Boris Androvsky (Charles Boyer), a strangely sorrowful man with a dark secret. They develop a friendship that grows into love but a chance encounter in the desert threatens all they hold dear.

results.title: High Sierra
results.creator_credit: Raoul Walsh, Hal B. Wallis, First National Pictures and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Newly released from prison, bank robber “Mad Dog” Roy Earle (Humphrey Bogart) agrees to one last caper, out of gratitude to an old gangland pal. However, Earle has changed after eight years in gaol. He is torn between his hard-boiled, brutal side and more caring, compassionate feelings, which ultimately cause his downfall. When getaway plans misfire, Earle flees to the High Sierras. In a defiant last stand he is trapped at 11,000 feet with an army of police waiting below.

results.title: The Heartbreak kid
results.creator_credit: Michael Jenkins, Ben Gannon and View Films Production
results.brief_description: Christina (Claudia Karvan) is a schoolteacher from a wealthy Greek-Australian background, engaged to a lawyer and content with the traditional course of her life. She begins teaching at an inner-city working-class school and she finds her ideas challenged by the students. Involving herself in a campaign by a group of non-anglo students to form a soccer club in a school where the racist PE teacher only supports Australian Rules Football, Christina starts falling in love with aspiring soccer player, 17 year old Nick (Alex Dimitriades). The ensuing affair forces Christina to challenge herself, her family and the culture she lives in. Managing to effectively combine comedy with a refreshing examination of contemporary ethnic relationships in Australia, beautifully acted by a young cast, and insightfully scripted, “The Heartbreak Kid” is a breakthrough film in an Australian film culture for too long dominated by narrow colonialist ideology. Based on the play by Richard Barrett.
